subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Rescission of Funds for Investing in Coastal Communities and Climate Resilience
sectionText:
SEC. 80201. RESCISSION OF FUNDS FOR INVESTING IN COASTAL COMMUNITIES 
              AND CLIMATE RESILIENCE.

    There is hereby rescinded the unobligated balance of funds made 
available by section 40001 of Public Law 117-169.
summary: Cancels every unspent dollar that the Inflation Reduction Act (§ 40001, P.L. 117‑169) appropriated to NOAA for coastal resilience grants, habitat restoration, and climate‑hazard mitigation.
impact:
• **Coastal risk rises.**  The IRA tranche targeted flood‑control dunes, living‑shoreline projects, and early‑warning systems; pulling the plug shifts billions in local match commitments onto states or terminates projects mid‑stream, increasing exposure to storm‑surge and sea‑level rise.
• **Whiplash for grantees.**  More than 100 announced awards are still finalising agreements; abrupt rescission invites breach‑of‑contract suits and erodes trust in future federal cost‑share programs.
• **Budget optics vs. disaster costs.**  Treasury savings (~$2.6 bn unobligated) are likely dwarfed by future FEMA disaster outlays that resilience projects were designed to avoid.
• **Scientific setback.**  NOAA’s new community climate‑service hubs, slated for these funds, are likely shelved, limiting local access to high‑resolution sea‑level projections.

subtitle: B
sectionTitle: Rescission of Funds for Facilities of NOAA and National Marine Sanctuaries
sectionText:
SEC. 80202. RESCISSION OF FUNDS FOR FACILITIES OF NATIONAL OCEANIC AND 
              ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION AND NATIONAL MARINE 
              SANCTUARIES.

    There is hereby rescinded the unobligated balance of funds made 
available by section 40002 of Public Law 117-169.
summary: Nullifies all unobligated Inflation Reduction Act (§ 40002) money earmarked for modernising NOAA laboratories, vessels, and National Marine Sanctuary facilities.
impact:
• **Dilutes U.S. weather‑prediction competitiveness.**  Lab renovations and super‑computing upgrades now unfunded could slow rollout of hurricane and wildfire forecast improvements promised for 2028.
• **Tourism & local‑economy hit.**  Sanctuary visitor‑center overhauls (e.g., Florida Keys, Monterey Bay) are likely cancelled—foregoing construction jobs and future fee revenue.
• **Asset‑management gap.**  NOAA’s deferred‑maintenance backlog already tops $800 million; rescission deepens it, raising long‑term costs as facilities age.
• **Marginal deficit gain.**  Savings (≈$1 bn unobligated) are tiny compared with NOAA’s annual disaster‑damage assessments that better observations could mitigate.

subtitle: B
sectionText:
SEC. 80203. SURFACE WATER STORAGE ENHANCEMENT.

    In addition to amounts otherwise available, there is appropriated 
to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Commissioner of 
Reclamation, for fiscal year 2025, out of any money in the Treasury not 
otherwise appropriated, $2,000,000,000, to remain available through 
September 30, 2034, for construction and associated activities that 
increase the capacity of existing Bureau of Reclamation surface water 
storage facilities, in a manner as determined by the Secretary: 
Provided, That, for the purposes of section 203 of the Reclamation 
Reform Act of 1982 (43 U.S.C. 390cc) or section 3404(a) of the 
Reclamation Projects Authorization and Adjustment Act of 1992 (Public 
Law 102-575), a contract or agreement entered into pursuant to this 
section shall not be treated as a new or amended contract. None of the 
funds provided under this section shall be reimbursable or subject to 
matching or cost-share requirements.
summary: Appropriates $2 billion (FY 2025–2034) to the Bureau of Reclamation for enlarging existing reservoirs and other federal surface‑storage projects.  Funds are **non‑reimbursable** and **exempt from cost‑share rules**, meaning 100 % federal pay‑out.
impact:
• **Subsidy revival.**  Waiving repayment and cost‑sharing re‑creates pre‑1982 reclamation subsidies, effectively gifting large western irrigation districts and power users new capacity without local financial stake.
• **Environmental litigation magnet.**  Enlarging dams often triggers ESA, NEPA and tribal water‑right conflicts; the bill provides no streamlining, risking decade‑long court fights that idle the $2 bn.
• **Climate‑resilience trade‑off.**  Money flows exclusively to more storage rather than demand‑side conservation or groundwater recharge, conflicting with modern water‑management science that emphasises portfolio approaches.
• **Opportunity cost.**  Non‑reimbursable outlays crowd out revenue‑generating investments (e.g., pumped hydro) and reduce reclaimable receipts to the Treasury.

subtitle: B
sectionText:
SEC. 80204. WATER CONVEYANCE ENHANCEMENT.

    In addition to amounts otherwise available, there is appropriated 
to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Commissioner of 
Reclamation, for fiscal year 2025, out of any money in the Treasury not 
otherwise appropriated, $500,000,000, to remain available through 
September 30, 2034, for construction and associated activities that 
restore or increase the capacity of existing Bureau of Reclamation 
conveyance facilities, in a manner as determined by the Secretary. None 
of the funds provided under this section shall be reimbursable or 
subject to matching or cost-share requirements.
summary: Provides $500 million (FY 2025–2034) in fully federal funding for repairing or enlarging existing Bureau of Reclamation canals, aqueducts, and pipelines, again exempting projects from any repayment or local match.
impact:
• **Fixes leaks, but skews incentives.**  Restoring capacity in century‑old canals (e.g., Central Valley Project) can save water, yet 0 % cost‑share dulls incentives for districts to curb conveyance losses on their own dime.
• **Potential ESA fast‑track conflicts.**  Canal‑lining projects can dewater riparian habitat; without explicit environmental guardrails, funds may meet legal roadblocks similar to past Friant‑Kern litigation.
• **Equity questions.**  Concentrates benefits in western irrigation districts while Tribes and small rural water systems—often lacking conveyance at all—receive no direct support.
• **Budgetary precedent.**  Setting storage *and* conveyance at full federal cost could spark parallel demands from Army Corps, raising future outlay expectations.
